column1: What is chronic pain and how does it work? – video explainer

Research suggests that the immune system plays a role in nociplastic pain, giving people 'feel bad' symptoms including fatigue, anxiety and nausea

In the centre Vladimir Petkovic, the manager who was five well-executed penalties from leading them into uncharted territory, rallied his shattered troops one last time. They had won this way once; now they had to win like this all over again.
column3: Nick Ames at St Petersburg Stadium

column1: The injecting centre that saved Lisa’s life
column2: Three years ago, when Lisa Townsend walked into a medically supervised injecting centre, she had been addicted to heroin, on and off, for 25 years. The benefits of supervised injecting facilities are well established, but that centre is one of only two of its kind in Australia, and plans for a third – in Melbourne’s CBD – have provoked a backlash. Science writer Donna Lu explores how these facilities work and Townsend reveals how one of them, and the people inside it, saved her life

'Up the front' to 'it's not a race': how Australia's bungled Covid vaccine rollout unfolded – video
column2: Australia's Covid vaccination program has lacked urgency at every stage, with the government forced to revise its own targets and never seeming to meet its own goals. The latest New South Wales outbreak has exposed the Morrison government's failure to successfully get the vaccine out to even the most vulnerable in the community. The outbreak has hit unvaccinated aged care workers, despite federal promises they would be vaccinated by March. Along with mixed messages about the urgency of getting Australia vaccinated, the Morrison government became mired in a debate about whether Australia’s coronavirus vaccination rollout is or is not a race

column1: Wimbledon day nine: Hurkacz stuns Federer as Djokovic, Shapovalov, Berrettini win – video highlights
column2: Novak Djokovic has reached his 10th Wimbledon semi-final after beating Márton Fucsovics in three sets. Hubert Hurkacz humbled eight-time winner Roger Federer, the Swiss 39-year-old tight-lipped on whether this will be his last appearance in the tournament. Canada's Denis Shapovalov took five sets to overcome Karen Khachanov while Matteo Berrettini beat Felix Auger Aliassime in four sets

column1: Gladys Berejiklian: NSW 'won't live' with Covid Delta variant without widespread vaccination – video
column2: While providing the latest NSW Covid update in Thursday's press conference, premier Gladys Berejiklian said New South Wales won't live with Covid until there is widespread vaccination of the population. 'What is apparent is that – and this has been demonstrated by every other place in the world, and we can’t pretend we’re different in&nbsp;NSW in Australia – is that&nbsp;you can’t live with the Delta variant unless you have a certain proportion of the population vaccinated,' she says. Berejiklian describes the Delta variant as a game-changer, adding that she is pushing to expedite the vaccination process in the state. There have been 395 locally acquired coronavirus cases reported since the latest Delta outbreak began on 16 June.

column1: Germany floods: stranded residents rescued by helicopter from rooftops – video
column2: At least 58 people have died and dozens more were missing in Germany on Thursday as swollen rivers caused by record rainfall across western Europe swept through towns and villages. Many of the victims died around the wine-growing region of Ahrweiler, in Rhineland-Palatinate state, police said, and dozens were still unaccounted for, after the Ahr river that flows into the Rhine broke its banks and brought down half a dozen houses

column1: Vanuatu’s golden passports
column2: A Guardian investigation has revealed that a scheme allowing foreign nationals to purchase citizenship in Vanuatu saw more than 2,000 people granted “golden passports” – and with it visa-free access to the EU and UK – in 2020. Among them are senior political figures from around the world, as well as several convicted and alleged criminals. While such citizenship schemes are not illegal or unusual, some experts have warned that this system could create a backdoor for criminals to enter the EU, and may encourage illegal operations in the broader Pacific area. Pacific Editor Kate Lyons and freelance reporter Euan Ward speak to Laura Murphy-Oates about how this passport scheme works and how it could be exploited
column3: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Euan Ward; produced by Ellen Leabeater, Joe Koning, Camilla Hannan, Allison Chan, Kate Lyons and Jane Lee. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

column1: Nepal’s National Paddy Day – in pictures
column2: Nepal celebrated National Paddy Day on 29 June. On this day, known as Asar Pandhra, farmers begin the annual rice planting season and mark the day with various festivities such as preparing rice meals with muddy water; mud being a symbol for a prosperous season. Sixty per cent of Nepal’s agriculture industry relies on monsoon rain, while 40% is carried out through irrigation. Agriculture is a major contributor to the country’s GDP

The moment took place in the middle of a small tournament final in Achocalla. The powerful wind can be seen dragging clothes into the air as the teams disperse to avoid being hit by the whirlwind.&nbsp;

column1: I’ve taken up golf – am I at risk of becoming everything I once hated? | Romesh Ranganathan
column2: gt; with my friend Rob Beckett, the comedian, and had a look at the world of golf. Rob had been playing a bit and trying to persuade me of the benefits of taking it up. I was unsure. The whole thing felt a little bit tragic: men of a certain age using four hours at the course as a way to escape their home life. I am also never really enamoured of the idea of members’ clubs and rules. If a club won’t let me in, I can only assume that it is exclusive and stuffy. If it will let me in, I assume it must be crap. The idea of membership is a great way to generate false demand for something that people wouldn’t feel anywhere near as excited about if everyone had access.

column1: Mountain of Salt: a Covid commentary from found images – in pictures
column2: Bindi Vora’s Mountain of Salt is a collection of found images and appropriated text conceived as a response to the Covid pandemic. The wry, sometimes humorous, text-based series of collages focuses on the language used over the past year and was developed from collecting words and sentences derived from politicians, journalists and other individuals. Vora says she is ‘interested in how we might unite and reflect on this time currently being experienced in our individual and collective ways, as we all live in the hope of clambering out and making it to the other side unscathed. This curious collection of phrases speaks to the dissemination of language and its effect upon us’

Similar scenes unfolded in Melbourne and Adelaide, which are both in lockdown, and Brisbane, which is not.

column1: NSW records 177 Covid-19 cases as the Sydney lockdown is extended for four weeks – video
column2: New South Wales premier&nbsp;Gladys Berejiklian&nbsp;has announced Sydney’s lockdown will been extended for another four weeks after 177 new local cases of Covid-19 were recorded, with at least 68 people in the community while infectious. A woman in her 90s has died. Restrictions that limit workers allowed to leave their local government area will be extended to Parramatta, Georges River and Campbelltown LGAs. They join the Fairfield, Canterbury-Bankstown, Liverpool, Cumberland and Blacktown LGAs. The premier has also announced restrictions will be slightly eased in Fairfield, with only aged care and healthcare workers leaving the LGA for work now required to get tested every three days

column1: The ‘Witch of Darwin’
column2: During the 1990s, Marie Cameron was known as the Witch of Darwin. It’s not a title she chose for herself but one she was given by the media, after a traditional Scandinavian bonfire, or ‘witch burning’, turned to violence. The events of that night would divide the community for years to come, with a media circus, a court battle, a protest, and the formation of a ‘council of witches’.

column1: Climate crisis: what one month of extreme weather looks like – video
column2: In the last month, devastating weather extremes have hit regions across the world. From flash floods in Belgium to deadly temperatures in the US, from wildfires in Siberia to landslides in India, it has been an unprecedented period of chaotic weather. Climate scientists have long predicted that human-caused climate disruption would lead to more flooding, heatwaves, droughts, storms and other forms of extreme weather, but even they have been shocked by the scale of these scenes

column1: Australia’s 2021 National Photographic Portrait prize winner and finalists – in pictures
column2: Sydney photographer Joel B Pratley’s photo of a lone farmer immersed in a dust storm in drought-stricken Australia has won the 2021 National Photographic Portrait prize. Titled Drought Story, the image shows David Kalisch captured amid a sudden dust storm on his 1,000-acre farm in Forbes, New South Wales. Pratley said his subject’s stance reflects the resilience of a man pushed to the limits by an unforgiving climate: ‘David’s composure during the storm was surreal, because he is just so used to it. For me, it was like being on Mars.’

column1: Nobody in ICU fully vaccinated: how one small mistake became fodder for conspiracy theorists – video
column2: During a Covid-19 press conference, NSW health offical Jeremy McAnulty ‘misspoke’ and inferred that all Covid patients in intensive care had been vaccinated when in fact none of them had been fully vaccinated. The video of the mistake has been widely shared on social media. A&nbsp;single post on one Australian page which regularly shares vaccination misinformation had more than 1,800 'interactions', including almost 300 'shares'. In less regulated online spaces, the video has been shared globally among conspiracist groups. In US-based Telegram groups clips of the video have been seen tens of thousands of times across various groups. Some called it evidence the vaccine is 'deadly gene therapy' and 'pure poison'. The Guardian also saw posts sharing the video in Telegram pages in Europe and the UK

column1: A portrait of black lives in Suffolk – in pictures
column2: Black Suffolk is a series of portraits by photographer John Ferguson of people from Suffolk’s African-Caribbean community. The pictures will be on display in an outdoor exhibition in central Ipswich from 30 July and throughout August. Ferguson said: ‘I have produced a new collection of portraits which explore the concept of home for a diversity of people in the African-Caribbean community in Suffolk. This theme creatively expresses people’s experience and interpretation of what exactly is home. Home can be a feeling, a physical space or a geographical place. Home can be a memory, metaphor or experience. The idea is to connect with the notion that our lives are inextricably attached to where we live, our homes, and Suffolk.’

column1: NSW Covid update: 170 new coronavirus cases as premier pleads with Sydney to stay home – video
column2: New South Wales premier Gladys Berejiklian pleads with Sydney residents to remain in their homes as 170 new Covid cases are recorded. She warns against attending anti-lockdown protests at the weekend. 'Do not give those you love the most a death sentence,' she says. 'This Delta strain is contagious, it's deadly and it's&nbsp;affecting people of all ages.' Chief health officer Kerry Chant says people are delaying seeking treatment, which affects the care that can be offered. She says her key message is get tested quickly if you have any symptoms including cough, fever, headache, loss of taste and smell, sore throat or muscle aches and pains. 'Just please, never be fearful of coming&nbsp;to a health services for care,' she says

column1: Pollution turns Argentina lake pink – video
column2: Drone footage shows the Corfo lagoon in the Chubut province, which has been tinted pink because toxic waste from fishing has been dumped into it. Experts and activists say the pollution is caused by a chemical used to preserve prawns for export. The colour is caused by sodium sulphite, an antibacterial product used in fish factories. Local residents have complained about the foul smells and pollution concerns around the Chubut River that feeds into the Corfo lagoon. In protest against the continued pollution, locals have blocked roads used by fish waste trucks from entering the area
